key_insight: BOAD automatically discovers a hierarchy of specialized software-engineering agents and uses bandit optimization to compose and adapt them, yielding better generalization on long-horizon, out-of-distribution coding tasks than monolithic single-agent chains.
problem_solved: Monolithic LLM agents struggle with long-horizon, real-world software engineering: they retain irrelevant context, learn spurious correlations, and fail to generalize across large, complex codebases and multi-step workflows.
method: Decompose the SWE workflow into modular roles and instantiate specialist agents for sub-tasks (e.g., issue interpretation, code navigation, patch generation).
Use bandit optimization to discover and adapt hierarchical agent compositions and routing policies that maximize task-level performance.
Evaluate agents through interaction with large codebases and long-horizon benchmarks to select robust, generalizable hierarchies.
impact: Modular, automatically optimized agent hierarchies reduce brittleness and improve success on complex software tasks, enabling more reliable AI-assisted coding and scalable workflows for ML and engineering teams.
visual_elements: Hierarchy diagram showing top-level controller agent routing to specialized sub-agents (interpret → search → implement → test).
Flowchart of bandit optimization loop: propose agent composition → evaluate on task → update selection policy.
Bar/line chart comparing BOAD vs single-agent baselines on long-horizon benchmark success rates and error reduction.
Icon set representing key roles (issue reader, code navigator, patch writer, tester) and a large-codebase backdrop to convey scale.
paper_title: BOAD: Discovering Hierarchical Software Engineering Agents via Bandit Optimization
paper_authors: Iris Xu, Guangtao Zeng, Zexue He, Charles Jin, Aldo Pareja
